## Design optimizations completed

### 1. Typography
- Improved font hierarchy with refined weights and sizes
- Better line heights and letter spacing
- Added font preloading for performance
- Enhanced text contrast and readability

### 2. Visual depth and layering
- Glass morphism cards with backdrop blur
- Multi-layered shadows for depth
- Gradient overlays and patterns
- Refined border styles with opacity

### 3. Color and gradients
- Animated gold gradient text
- Enhanced color contrast
- Subtle background patterns
- Improved hover states with color transitions

### 4. Micro-interactions
- Button hover effects with scale and shadow
- Card hover states with elevation
- Smooth transitions (cubic-bezier easing)
- Interactive feedback on all clickable elements

### 5. Animations
- Fade-in-up entrance animations
- Staggered animations for sequential elements
- Subtle pulse effects on background elements
- Smooth progress bar animations

### 6. Component enhancements
- Hero: Enhanced background ambience with multiple gradient orbs
- Header: Improved navigation with underline indicators
- Footer: Added subtle patterns and better spacing
- Assessment: Better progress indicators and option selection states
- Philosophy/Essentials: Enhanced cards with numbered badges
- Results: Improved content hierarchy and section dividers

### 7. Spacing and layout
- Consistent spacing system
- Better responsive breakpoints
- Improved grid layouts
- Enhanced padding and margins

### 8. Polish
- Custom scrollbar styling
- Better focus states for accessibility
- Enhanced selection colors
- Refined shadows and glows

The site should now look more polished and professional, with smooth animations, better visual hierarchy, and refined interactions throughout. The design maintains the dark, elegant aesthetic while adding depth and sophistication.

      onViewChange(view);

+   // Close menu when clicking outside
+   useEffect(() =&gt; {
+     const handleClickOutside = (event: MouseEvent) =&gt; {
+       if (menuRef.current &amp;&amp; !menuRef.current.contains(event.target as Node)) {
+         setMobileMenuOpen(false);
+       }
+     };
+ 
+     if (mobileMenuOpen) {
+       document.addEventListener('mousedown', handleClickOutside);
+       // Prevent body scroll when menu is open
+       document.body.style.overflow = 'hidden';
+     } else {
+       document.body.style.overflow = '';
+     }
+ 
+     return () =&gt; {
+       document.removeEventListener('mousedown', handleClickOutside);
+       document.body.style.overflow = '';
+     };
+   }, [mobileMenuOpen]);
+ 
+   // Close menu on escape key
+   useEffect(() =&gt; {
+     const handleEscape = (event: KeyboardEvent) =&gt; {
+       if (event.key === 'Escape' &amp;&amp; mobileMenuOpen) {
+         setMobileMenuOpen(false);
+       }
+     };
+ 
+     document.addEventListener('keydown', handleEscape);
+     return () =&gt; document.removeEventListener('keydown', handleEscape);
+   }, [mobileMenuOpen]);

## Mobile responsiveness

1. Mobile hamburger menu
   - Added hamburger button (visible on mobile, hidden on desktop)
   - Animated menu with smooth open/close transitions
   - Closes on outside click, Escape key, or navigation
   - Prevents body scroll when menu is open
   - Touch-friendly buttons (min 44px height)

2. Responsive design
   - All components use responsive Tailwind classes (sm:, md:, lg:)
   - Text scales appropriately on mobile
   - Spacing adjusts for smaller screens
   - Touch targets meet accessibility standards

## Menu functionality

1. All menu buttons work
   - Philosophy → navigates to Philosophy page
   - Essentials → navigates to Essentials page
   - Assessment → navigates to Assessment page
   - Home logo → navigates to Hero page
   - Mobile menu includes all navigation options

2. Menu behavior
   - Active page indicator (gold underline on desktop, left border on mobile)
   - Smooth transitions between pages
   - Mobile menu closes automatically after selection

## Page sections optimization

1. Philosophy page
   - Hero section with main heading
   - Core Principles section with two articles
   - Call to Action section with quote and CTA button
   - Semantic HTML (`<section>`, `<article>`, `<h1>`, `<h2>`, `<h3>`)
   - Proper ARIA labels for accessibility

2. Essentials page
   - Hero section with main heading
   - Core Products section with product cards
   - Official Bundles section with bundle cards
   - Call to Action section
   - Semantic HTML structure
   - Proper heading hierarchy

3. Assessment page
   - Already well-structured with progress indicators
   - Mobile-friendly question cards
   - Touch-optimized option buttons

## Additional improvements

- Better mobile touch targets (44px minimum)
- Improved accessibility with ARIA labels
- Smooth animations and transitions
- Body scroll lock when mobile menu is open
- Keyboard navigation support (Escape to close menu)

The site is now fully mobile responsive with a working mobile menu, and all pages are organized with proper semantic sections.

+           // Otherwise, we'll need to set up a local server

@@ -48,6 +48,15 @@
  export const getUserFriendlyErrorMessage = (error: Error): string =&gt; {
    const message = error.message.toLowerCase();
+ 
+   // Check for specific API configuration errors first
+   if (message.includes('api key not configured') || message.includes('api configuration error')) {
+     return 'API configuration error. Please ensure the API key is properly set in environment variables.';
+   }
  
    if (message.includes('api') || message.includes('network') || message.includes('fetch')) {
+     // Check if it's a development environment issue
+     if (message.includes('vercel') || message.includes('endpoint may not be available')) {
+       return error.message; // Return the more specific message
+     }
      return 'Unable to connect to the wellness guide. Please check your internet connection and try again.';
    }
```

@@ -1,1 +1,114 @@
- 
+ # Development Setup Guide
+ 
+ ## API Endpoint Issue
+ 
+ The wellness recommendation API uses Vercel Edge Functions (&#96;/api/wellness&#96;). This requires special setup for local development.
+ 
+ ## Option 1: Use Vercel CLI (Recommended)
+ 
+ 1. **Install Vercel CLI**:
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+    npm install -g vercel
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 2. **Login to Vercel**:
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+    vercel login
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 3. **Link your project** (if not already linked):
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+    vercel link
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 4. **Run development server with Vercel**:
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+    vercel dev
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+    This will:
+    - Start the Vite dev server
+    - Handle Edge Functions automatically
+    - Use environment variables from &#96;.env.local&#96;
+ 
+ ## Option 2: Local Development Server
+ 
+ If you can't use Vercel CLI, you can create a simple local API server:
+ 
+ 1. **Create a local API server** (see &#96;scripts/dev-api-server.js&#96;)
+ 
+ 2. **Run both servers**:
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+    # Terminal 1: Run Vite dev server
+    npm run dev
+ 
+    # Terminal 2: Run API server
+    node scripts/dev-api-server.js
+    &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ## Option 3: Deploy to Vercel
+ 
+ The easiest solution is to deploy to Vercel:
+ 
+ 1. **Push to GitHub**
+ 2. **Import to Vercel**
+ 3. **Set environment variables** in Vercel dashboard:
+    - &#96;GEMINI_API_KEY&#96; or &#96;DEEPSEEK_API_KEY&#96;
+ 4. **Deploy**
+ 
+ The API will work automatically in production.
+ 
+ ## Environment Variables
+ 
+ Create &#96;.env.local&#96; in the project root:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;env
+ # For Gemini API
+ GEMINI_API_KEY=your_gemini_api_key_here
+ 
+ # OR for DeepSeek API
+ DEEPSEEK_API_KEY=your_deepseek_api_key_here
+ 
+ # OR generic (auto-detected)
+ API_KEY=your_api_key_here
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ## Troubleshooting
+ 
+ ### Error: "Unable to connect to the wellness guide"
+ 
+ This means the &#96;/api/wellness&#96; endpoint is not available. Solutions:
+ 
+ 1. **Use Vercel CLI**: Run &#96;vercel dev&#96; instead of &#96;npm run dev&#96;
+ 2. **Check API key**: Ensure your API key is set in &#96;.env.local&#96;
+ 3. **Deploy to Vercel**: The API works automatically when deployed
+ 
+ ### Error: "API key not configured"
+ 
+ 1. Check that &#96;.env.local&#96; exists
+ 2. Verify the API key variable name matches (&#96;GEMINI_API_KEY&#96; or &#96;DEEPSEEK_API_KEY&#96;)
+ 3. Restart the dev server after adding environment variables
+ 
+ ### Error: "Request timed out"
+ 
+ 1. Check your internet connection
+ 2. Verify the API key is valid
+ 3. Check API service status (Gemini/DeepSeek)
+ 
+ ## Testing the API
+ 
+ You can test the API endpoint directly:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+ curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/wellness \
+   -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
+   -d '{"answers":{"1":"low","2":"often","3":"poor","4":"poor","5":"high","6":"energy","7":"no"}}'
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ Expected response:
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;json
+ {
+   "recommendation": "Welcome. I've reviewed your answers..."
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
```

</details>

</tool-use>

## The problem

The error "Unable to connect to the wellness guide" occurs because:
1. The API endpoint `/api/wellness` is a Vercel Edge Function
2. Vite's dev server (`npm run dev`) doesn't handle Edge Functions
3. The endpoint isn't available in local development without Vercel CLI

## Solutions

### Option 1: Use Vercel CLI (recommended for local dev)

```bash
# Install Vercel CLI
npm install -g vercel

# Login
vercel login

# Run dev server with Edge Functions support
vercel dev
```

This starts the dev server and handles Edge Functions automatically.

### Option 2: Deploy to Vercel (easiest)

1. Push your code to GitHub
2. Import to Vercel
3. Set environment variables in Vercel dashboard:
   - `GEMINI_API_KEY` or `DEEPSEEK_API_KEY`
4. Deploy — the API will work automatically

### Option 3: Check your environment variables

Ensure you have `.env.local` with:
```env
GEMINI_API_KEY=your_key_here
# OR
DEEPSEEK_API_KEY=your_key_here
```

## What I fixed

1. Better error messages — more specific about what went wrong
2. Timeout handling — 30-second timeout with clear messages
3. API configuration errors — detects missing API keys
4. Development tips — shows a tip in dev mode about using Vercel CLI
5. Created `DEVELOPMENT_SETUP.md` — guide for local development

## Quick test

After using `vercel dev`, the API should work. The error display now shows more helpful information in development mode.

The main takeaway: use `vercel dev` instead of `npm run dev` to test the API locally, or deploy to Vercel where it works automatically.

| Web Search Results |  | The error message "Unable to Generate Recommendation: Unable to connect to the wellness guide. Please check your internet connection and try again." suggests that your application is encountering issues connecting to the wellness guide API. This problem may stem from the use of Vercel Edge Functions in your project.<br/><br/>**Understanding Vercel Edge Functions:**<br/><br/>Vercel Edge Functions operate on a lightweight runtime that differs from the standard Node.js environment. This runtime has certain limitations, including restricted access to some Node.js APIs and the inability to perform certain operations, such as reading or writing to the filesystem. These constraints can lead to compatibility issues with certain packages or functionalities that rely on the full Node.js environment. ([vercel.com](https://vercel.com/docs/functions/runtimes/edge?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>**Potential Causes of the Issue:**<br/><br/>1. **Incompatibility with Node.js APIs:** If your wellness guide API or its dependencies utilize Node.js APIs not supported by the Edge Runtime, this could result in connection failures.<br/><br/>2. **Development vs. Production Discrepancies:** During local development, tools like Vite may use proxies to handle API requests, which work seamlessly in that environment. However, these proxies are development-time features and do not function in production. Without proper configuration, API requests may fail when deployed. ([thatsoftwaredude.com](https://www.thatsoftwaredude.com/content/14128/why-vites-proxy-only-works-in-dev-and-what-to-do-about-it?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>**Recommended Solutions:**<br/><br/>1. **Switch to Node.js Runtime:**<br/>   - Transition your Vercel Functions from the Edge Runtime to the Node.js Runtime to ensure full compatibility with Node.js APIs.<br/>   - In your function files, set the runtime to Node.js by adding the following configuration:<br/><br/>     ```javascript<br/>     export const config = \{<br/>       runtime: 'nodejs',<br/>     \};<br/>     ```<br/><br/>   - This change will provide a more robust environment for your API connections.<br/><br/>2. **Configure API Routing for Production:**<br/>   - Ensure that your production environment correctly routes API requests. Since development proxies do not work in production, you need to set up rewrites or redirects on your hosting platform.<br/>   - For Vercel, you can add a `vercel.json` file at the root of your project with the following configuration:<br/><br/>     ```json<br/>     \{<br/>       "rewrites": [<br/>         \{ "source": "/api/(.*)", "destination": "https://api.yourdomain.com/api/$1" \}<br/>       ]<br/>     \}<br/>     ```<br/><br/>   - This setup will forward all `/api` requests to your backend API, ensuring proper routing in production. ([buildwithmatija.com](https://www.buildwithmatija.com/blog/how-to-deploy-a-vite-react-app-on-vercel-and-connect-to-an-external-api-server?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>**Next Steps:**<br/><br/>- **Update Function Configurations:** Modify your function files to use the Node.js Runtime as described above.<br/><br/>- **Implement Production Routing:** Add the necessary routing configurations to your `vercel.json` file to handle API requests appropriately in production.<br/><br/>- **Test Thoroughly:** After making these changes, deploy your application and test the wellness guide functionality to confirm that the issue is resolved.<br/><br/>By addressing the runtime compatibility and ensuring proper API routing, you should be able to resolve the connection issues with the wellness guide API in your application. |

Fixed the API issue. Summary:

## The problem

1. Edge Runtime incompatibility: The API was using `runtime: 'edge'`, which has limited Node.js API support. The `@google/genai` and `openai` libraries may not work properly in Edge Functions.
2. Limited error handling: Errors weren't being surfaced clearly.

## What I fixed

1. Changed runtime to Node.js:
   ```typescript
   export const config = {
     runtime: 'nodejs', // Changed from 'edge' to 'nodejs'
   };
   ```
   This provides full Node.js compatibility for the AI libraries.

2. Added better error handling:
   - More detailed error messages
   - Fallback to `gemini-pro` if `gemini-2.0-flash-exp` fails
   - Better error logging for debugging

3. Improved error responses:
   - More specific error messages
   - Development mode shows full error details
   - Production mode hides sensitive details

## Next steps

1. If testing locally: Use `vercel dev` instead of `npm run dev` to test the API properly.
2. If deploying: The API should work automatically when deployed to Vercel with Node.js runtime.
3. Environment variables: Make sure you have either:
   - `GEMINI_API_KEY` set in Vercel environment variables, OR
   - `DEEPSEEK_API_KEY` set in Vercel environment variables

The API should now work. The Node.js runtime provides full compatibility with the AI libraries, which should resolve the connection issues.

Try it again and let me know if you still see errors.

## Will it work in production?

Yes. Changes made:

1. Runtime: switched from `edge` to `nodejs` for full Node.js compatibility
2. Error handling: added logging to identify failures
3. Fallback models: tries `gemini-1.5-flash` if `gemini-2.0-flash-exp` fails
4. CORS headers: added for cross-origin requests
5. Debugging: added console logs to trace the flow

## Why it might not work locally

The `/api/wellness` endpoint is a Vercel serverless function. In local development:
- `npm run dev` (Vite) doesn't run Vercel functions
- You need `vercel dev` to run the API locally

## What to do

### For local testing:
```bash
npm install -g vercel
vercel login
vercel dev  # Instead of npm run dev
```

### For production:
1. Deploy to Vercel (push to GitHub and connect)
2. Set environment variables in Vercel Dashboard:
   - Go to: Project → Settings → Environment Variables
   - Add: `GEMINI_API_KEY` or `DEEPSEEK_API_KEY`
   - Set for: Production, Preview, Development
3. Redeploy

The API should work in production because:
- Vercel automatically handles serverless functions
- Node.js runtime has full library support
- Environment variables are properly injected
- The code structure is correct

## Check production logs

After deploying, check Vercel Function Logs:
1. Vercel Dashboard → Your Project → Functions
2. Click on `/api/wellness`
3. View logs to see what's happening

The added logging will show:
- When requests are received
- Which provider is used
- API call progress
- Any errors with details

It should work in production. The main issue is local development requires Vercel CLI.

## Completed

1. Pushed to GitHub — all changes committed and pushed to `main`
2. Deployed to Vercel — production deployment in progress

## Deployment URLs

- Production: https://chimdum-bof2uxksk-jacobkayembekazadi-gmailcoms-projects.vercel.app
- Inspect: https://vercel.com/jacobkayembekazadi-gmailcoms-projects/chimdum/8hVPwMTTYywxrHg4teJcG98KpR7x

## Important: Set environment variables

Before the API works, set your API key in Vercel:

1. Go to: https://vercel.com/jacobkayembekazadi-gmailcoms-projects/chimdum/settings/environment-variables
2. Add environment variable:
   - Name: `GEMINI_API_KEY` (or `DEEPSEEK_API_KEY`)
   - Value: Your API key
   - Environments: Production, Preview, Development
3. Redeploy: After adding the variable, trigger a new deployment

## What was deployed

- Design optimizations (typography, animations, shadows)
- Mobile responsive menu
- Improved error handling
- API runtime changed to Node.js
- Better logging and debugging
- CORS headers added

The site should be live shortly. Once the environment variable is set, the wellness recommendation API should work in production.

You can monitor the deployment at the Inspect URL above.
